DOCNAME: CASE OF KARADEMİRCİ AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE .

The first applicant , PERSON , who was the president of ORG ( Tüm PERSON ) , read out a statement signed by the GPE branches of that union and of ORG ) denouncing the ill - treatment of pupils from the GPE NORP PERSON secondary school . The group remained outside the school for TIME before dispersing .
CARDINAL . The statement reads as follows :
“ To the press and the general public

The pressure put on pupils by the authorities at the GPE PERSON secondary school has resulted in PERSON receiving a beating . The pupils reacted by protesting against the school authorities because of the pressure they were under . In an initial attempt to calm down the pupils , whose reaction was justified , the authorities held a meeting with them . However , they reneged on a promise to open an inquiry into the actions of CARDINAL of the teachers , ORG , who , moreover , was provided with a forensic report .
The pressure continues in the form of a lengthy ( DATE ) suspension of CARDINAL pupils , and the deduction of MONEY from their marks for behaviour .
Although officially pupils in the school are not subjected to beatings or academic pressure , the administrators are despots .

We call for an investigation into the conduct of the teacher who administered the beating .

CARDINAL . By an indictment submitted on DATE , the public prosecutor instituted criminal proceedings against CARDINAL leaders and members of ORG and ORG for making a “ statement to the press ” ( basın açıklaması ) without complying with the statutory requirement to obtain a receipt from the public prosecutor 's office confirming that they had filed a copy of the statement with it . The public prosecutor relied in particular on DATE and CARDINAL of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL of DATE ) .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG found the applicants and CARDINAL other co - defendants guilty as charged and sentenced them to DATE imprisonment under the provisions relied on by the public prosecutor . The prison sentence was commuted to a suspended fine of MONEY ( MONEY ) .

CARDINAL . ORG held that the constitutive elements of the offence had been made out in that , firstly , the trade unions had not passed a resolution authorising a statement to be made to the press and , secondly , the accused were present when the statement was read out in public . The other co - defendants were acquitted on the ground that they were not present when the statement was read out .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed to ORG against that judgment . In their written submissions , they alleged that their convictions violated their right to freedom of expression and , in particular , that “ a statement to the press ” could not be classified as a “ leaflet ” or “ written statement ” within the meaning of section CARDINAL of LAW .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG upheld the judgment at first instance , holding that it complied with the law and the rules of procedure . The applicants did not receive a full copy of the judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the judgment of DATE was placed in the file of ORG . The sixth applicant , PERSON , obtained a copy of it on DATE .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW , which was published in ORG on DATE , are as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG shall not publish or distribute leaflets [ bildiri ] , written statements [ beyanname ] or similar publications [ benzeri yayın ] without a prior resolution by their executive board . The leaflets , written statements and similar publications shall contain the forenames , surnames and signatures of the president and members of the executive board which passed the resolution .

( CARDINAL ) A copy of the resolution by the association 's executive board to publish and of the leaflet , written statement or similar publication shall be filed for information purposes with the head of the local authority and the public prosecutor 's office for the area . The latter shall deliver , in exchange , a receipt recording the time and date the documents were filed . No leaflet , written statement or similar publication may be distributed or communicated to the press until TIME after it has been filed . ”
“ Anyone failing to comply with the procedure set out in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) shall be liable on conviction to DATE imprisonment . ”

CARDINAL . At the material time trade unions representing public servants were formed without any specific statutory basis . Associations and trade unions were governed by CARDINAL pieces of legislation : LAW and LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ) . Although there are no restrictions in LAW on written statements by trade unions , section CARDINAL refers to LAW and lays down that the provisions of that Act shall apply where LAW is silent .

CARDINAL . The first CARDINAL applicants produced various judgments that had been delivered by ORG in cases concerning the activities of public - sector trade unions . These included a judgment of DATE ( no . CARDINAL ) , from which it emerged that the first CARDINAL applicants had ultimately been acquitted in another case in which they had been charged with an offence under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW after reading out a statement to the press and distributing it to members of the press . In that case , ORG had followed a judgment of ORG ( without giving the reference ) in finding that a statement read out to the press drafted by ORG could not be classified as a “ written statement ” or “ similar publication ” within the meaning of section CARDINAL of LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE ORG , sitting as a full court , delivered CARDINAL judgments in which it clarified the issue of whether it was foreseeable that section CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of LAW applied to written statements read out to the press by members of an association 's executive board . In its view , those subsections applied to texts which had previously been adopted and prepared for publication and dissemination . However , a statement read out to the press by an association on a particular subject was not a text that was drafted with a view to publication and dissemination , but a series of verbal comments . “ Dissemination ” , “ publication ” and similar terms could not possibly cover the situation in which the content of a speech due to be made orally was distributed among members of the press as an aid to understanding . The effect of holding otherwise – by a broad interpretation of the law , CARDINAL which , in other words , included oral statements within the scope of section DATE would be that members of an association 's executive board would be liable to penalties for any replies or explanations given in response to questions from journalists ; such a state of affairs would introduce an unlawful restriction on freedoms . In addition , the legislature had unambiguously laid down in that section that a text drafted with a view to publication could be published only once the executive board of the association had so resolved and the relevant documents had been filed with the competent authority .

CARDINAL . Law no . CARDINAL , which ORG passed on DATE , amends LAW , repealing sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL . On DATE the President of the Republic returned the legislation to ORG for a fresh debate on sections DATE , which relate to the financing of associations .
